dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorraine, you're still here? That’s exactly where | left you last night. Lorraine squints through the smoke wafting up into her ey

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’m ready, Max. Nothing can stop me now.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You need to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (waves her hand) Nah! | slept all the time when | was young. (points) I’ve made 500 flyers, you think that’s enough?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | should think so.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: And you'll help me hand them out?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That's why I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Good. Y’know, Max, as I’ve stood here all night cranking this machine, it came to me that we’re standing at a crossroads.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: A crossroads to what?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: To anew age.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That's what they were all saying about Kennedy and Camelot and all that, but look what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: It's bigger than that.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yeah, | think you’ve been up too long.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Hopefully, it will be a time when stuff like this . . . (waves flyers) . .. won't happen anymore. | mean, if we don’t do something right away these five boys will spend the rest of their young lives in jail.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hey, you don’t have to convince me. But their pre-trial hearing is Monday. If they go in there with some cracker, redneck, court-appointed attorney, they'll get life for s

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | know! This could well be their last chance. That’s why it’s so important and that’s why I’m so nervous. This is the first important political action that I’ve personally organized. People just have to show up.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | mean, real people?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Gosh, thanks a lot. (Lorraine smiles) Look, it’s an important cause, why wouldn’t they show up?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (thinks) Um... to make me look bad?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Make you look bad to whom, if | may ask?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what this is all about, Lorraine? Looking good?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, not at all. It’s entirely about those five boys and the injustice that’s being done to them. | mean, if | don’t do something about it why should | expect anyone else to do anything, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: We all have to draw a line somewhere and say, “If you go beyond that line you have to deal with me, too.” At least, that’s what | think.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Right. Me, too. You could always just tackle people out in the street and drag ‘em in kicking and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | might yet.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | bet you would, too. But why do you do this, Lorraine, staying up all night, burning it at both ends?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Someone’s got to, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Do they? Why?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Because if nobody cares the whole world will go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: But, Lorraine, you can’t save the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, but | can try. And step one is getting everyone to care about this issue, the Springfield Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can’t actually make anyone else care about something, Lorraine. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure you can. These are old, time-worn techniques used by the wobblies before the war. But getting to a whole group at once, that’s the trick. That's where songs come in.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Yeah, but even songs won’t make someone care if they don't.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: If it's the right song being sung the right way.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | don’t think that’s true.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (off-handed) Sure it is. Deep down | honestly think that people really want to do what's right and actually do care, they just need a little push in the right direction to ge them going, and that’s where | come in. Lorraine reaches into her sweater pocket and pulls out a finds empty and crumples.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Gotta smoke?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: No. You're an idealist, Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I'm more than idealist, Max, I’m an instrument of God. Lorraine checks out the overflowing ashtray and spots a l out and lights it, then takes a sip of coffee. She winces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blah! How can coffee get colder than the room it’s in?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | don’t know. You going to the Purple Onion tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, sure. Got to. (she waves a pile of flyers) | have to get every single person at the Purple Onion tonight to come to my meeting Sunday. Those people are what | have to work with; they're my building materials and this meeting is my testing ground. If | have to yell and scream, I'll do it. If | have to whisper and sing songs, I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: And you dig it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, that, too. (snaps her fingers) That reminds me, have you got an extra guitar pick?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Not here. You can always use a matchbook.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: They shred. That’s OK, I'll swing by the music store. Lorraine sits down and puts on her shoes. Max checks out Suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Lorraine, you drive me crazy! Why won't you go out with me?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Look, Max, you’re my friend. Let’s leave it at that, OK?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But | don’t want to leave it at that.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: If there was something here, Max, we’d know about it by now, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: ! know about it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It takes two to tango.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: But what can | do, Lorraine? Lorraine smiles and hands Max a thick pile of flyers.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Here. Hand these out. See ya later, alligator. Lorraine walks out of the office and Max watches her go, left. EXT. “STUDENTS FOR POLITICAL ACTION” OFFICE — DAY Lorraine exits the office and strides up the street immed flyers.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Demand justice now! Free the Springfield Five! Most people take the flyers that are offered to them, alt discard them, some right on the street. When Lorraine see picks the flyer back up.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Slob!

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. THE BUCKLEY HOUSE — DAY  8 This is a small house in a neighborhood of nearly identic the shady street. A red 1960 Ford Falcon sits in the driv the Three Stooges playing on TV can be heard from within. the house. INT. THE BUCKLEY HOUSE/LIVING ROOM — DAY DAN BUCKLEY, a 14-year old wearing a Boy Scout uniform, s Stooges on TV and laughing. The doorbell rings. Dan dashe door. Two other 14-year old boys in Boy Scout uniforms co begin talking at once. Dan and his pals leave. MR. BUCKLEY and MRS. BUCKLEY enter the living room. Phil’ bowling shirt and holds a bowling ball up in front of his

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Be careful with that in the house.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Hon, please, I’ve got to get in the proper frame of mind, OK? (chuckles) Get it, “frame” of mind? Bowling. Frame

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: That's great, dear, you’re another Red Skelton.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (imitates Red Skelton’s lisp) Good night and God blesh. (looks around) Where's Phil?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Still in bed. Mr. Buckley looks at his watch and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: It’s after ten, what’s with him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: You tell me. Ever since he graduated high school and started work, he’s changed. He just doesn’t  seem to give a damn about anything anymore. | don’t know what to do with him. Mr. Buckley considers this for a moment, then exits the l INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE PHIL’S ROOM — DAY Phil’s Dad steps up to a closed bedroom door, tries the d

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Phil? You up?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be at work?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: | got the day off.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: It just happens that way sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Huh. Well, why don’t you get out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Why? What's the difference? Mrs. Buckley steps up beside her husband.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Because it’s a beautiful day.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful day here in my bed, too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: | don’t like this behavior, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: 10 Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. So get your ass out of bed!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, | will.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Do it soon.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: All right. OK.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Y’know, Phil, if you waste this day, you'll never get it back.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah? Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (to her husband) You see?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, | see.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: How the hell am | supposed to know? (he kisses his wife) | gotta go. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Bye. Phil’s Dad and Mom exit and we stay on Phil’s closed bedr INT. PHIL’S BEDROOM - DAY PHIL BUCKLEY, a tall, handsome, eighteen-year old boy wit  11 his boxer shorts smoking a cigarette. Phil wears a can op his neck. The ashtray beside his bed is overflowing with languidly, the smoke drifting up from his nose. There are doesn’t notice. Phil reaches under the bed and comes out with a can of be opener, guzzles, winces, grins and belches. Phil glances over at the wall beside him. There are many magazines, as well as pictures of Tuesday Weld, Chuck Ber Mantle. Phil suddenly sits up, reaches over and grabs an against the wall and begins strumming it. Phil plays a variety of tunes and rhythms in a half-assed very good. He glances over at a book on his desk, “Beginn book and begins to play. He’s doing OK until he attempts sadly, his fingers don’t want to stretch that way.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ouch! Phil shuts the book. He walks over to his dresser, steps his arms, lowers his chin and proceeds to do a poor Ed Su

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Tonight we have a really big shew. | mean, a really, really big shew. Let's all give a very warm welcome to the talented, amazing, one- of-a-kind Phil Buckley! (he imitates the fans cheering; smiling humbly he picks up his guitar and imitates Elvis) Thank you. Thank you very much. I'd like to play my newest song which has been (continued) PHIL (cont.) number-one on the hit parade for over three months... Phil sits down on the bed, strums his guitar, but still i He thinks for a second, then puts down the guitar and dig drawers. He comes up with a cheap old microphone with a s on the end. Phil considers this situation for a moment, t and deftly cuts off the plug. He then splits the wire and  12 Phil takes the mike over to his record player and connect the amplifier. Suddenly, feedback fills the room. Phil’s

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Boss! He moves the mike away from the amp, then blows into it a breath through his speakers. Phil takes the microphone an his guitar and presto! It’s electric! Now he really start not particularly talented, simply enthusiastic. He does t across his room, guitar wailing. INT. KITCHEN — DAY Phil’s Mom is doing the dishes. She hears the strange, el around.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What on Earth? INT. PHIL’S BEDROOM — DAY Phil’s a rock & roll maniac playing to thousands of adori until — sproing! — one of his guitar strings breaks. Phil He scrutinizes the money on his dresser — he has one doll Nevertheless, a guitar with a broken string seems like a up, finally motivated to do something. He puts his guitar begins putting on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. CITY STREETS — DAY Phil walks along the street carrying his guitar case. Phi anything going on around him. He’s got a tune in his head on his face. He occasionally makes an Elvis Presley-style a grunt and we realize that Phil’s still on The Ed Sulliv the crowd reaction sounds, cheering and laughing. The beatnik kid MAX from the “Students for Political Acti

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Free the Springfield Five! Let justice be done,  13 man. Meeting on Sunday at the Purple Onion. Phil waves it away entirely uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No thanks. INT. MUSIC STORE — DAY This is the all-purpose variety of music store that sells all the accessories. Lorraine stands before a large varie guitar and deliberates. She chooses a pick, checks its th its bin. Finally, Lorraine makes her decision, chooses a counter and pays the portly, middle-aged CLERK a quarter. Lorraine strolls over to the sheet music. She flips throu likes and pulls it out—it’s Woody Guthrie’s song “This La plays the first several chords, humming the tune. Somethi and she walks to another part of the store, stepping behi woodwind instruments. Just then Phil steps up in front of the woodwind case, th guitar section where Lorraine just stood. He finds the gu fifty cents, half of his accumulated wealth. Phil resigns replaces his broken string. He sees the portly Clerk watc guy. The Clerk smiles back. Lorraine hands a yellow flyer to an OLD BLACK WOMAN, who looks at it with interest. Now Phil attempts to tune his guitar. He does a rather ha good enough—then spots the open sheet music in front of h Land.” Phil concentrates deeply, furrowing his brow, and first few chords of the song.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (singing) This land is your land This land is my land From California To the New York Island From the redwood forests To the Gulf stream waters This land was made for you and me—  14 Lorraine steps up from behind and proclaims. . .

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I love this song! Phil turns around and checks Lorraine out. He smiles his

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Really? No kidding? Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (excited) Really? Come on, let’s play it together. Lorraine begins playing the song and Phil very hesitantly frequently at the lyrics.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (singing) As | went walking That ribbon of highway | saw above me That endless skyway | saw below me That golden valley This land was made for you and me (continued) LORRAINE & PHIL (cont.) This land is your land This land is my land From California To the New York Island From the redwood forests To the Gulf stream waters This land was made for you and me | roamed and rambled And | followed my footsteps To the sparkling sands Of her diamond deserts While all around me  15 A voice was sounding, sayin’, This land was made for you and me The sun came shining And | was strolling And the wheat fields waving And the dust clouds rolling As the fog was lifting A voice was chanting This land was made for you and me Suddenly, everybody in the store, including the old black for the finale.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: This land is your land This land is my land From California To the New York Island From the redwood forests To the Gulf stream waters This land was made for you and me This land was made for you and me Everybody laughs, then returns to their business. Lorrain

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Wow! Did you see the way the music draws people in? It’s fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it sure is. So, you like music, eh?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yes, very much. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Uh, my name’s Phil, what’s yours?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Lorraine. (he puts out his hand to shake and she hands him a yellow flyer) There’s a really important meeting tomorrow night for the Springfield Five.  16 Phil takes the flyer looking confused.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Is that a new band?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No! Don’t you read the newspaper?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sure, but | must've missed it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: It's been the headline for the last week.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: The neighbor’s dog grabs our paper all the time and chews it up. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: The Springfield Five are five colored boys that were arrested for no good reason as they were driving down south to a civil rights rally. We're trying to get them out of jail.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh. OK. Tomorrow night, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (frowns) But tomorrow's Sunday, y’know.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah? So?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, Ed Sullivan’s on Sunday at eight. Lorraine grimaces with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: 17 Oh, that’s too bad. I’m talking about real problems in the real world here.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | know, I’m just telling you that that’s not a good time for a meeting. Lorraine looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You think? | printed 500 flyers.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It may not mean anything, y'know, maybe he hasn’t got anyone good on the show this week. Lorraine suddenly looks like she’s got a headache. She re pocket and finds it empty.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Have you got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sure. Wanna get a cup of coffee to go with it? Lorraine looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (grins) OK. Caffeine and nicotine are my favorite food groups.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Don’t forget beer, it’s just like liquid bread. Lorraine laughs and she and Phil exit. INT. COFFEE HOUSE — DAY Phil and Lorraine both drink mugs of coffee and smoke cig

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Well, | worked for a while at a crisis phone line,  18 but | got really tired sitting up all night listening to drug addicts moan about not scoring and pretending to be a marriage counselor. | didn’t really feel like | was part of the fight.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (Phil nods, mesmerized) Right. Lorraine really looks at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Do you know what | mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Haven't you ever had a feeling of pure empathy?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (thinks, then shakes his head) I'm not sure. What's empathy?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: It’s like sympathy, only you don’t feel bad for someone, you feel bad with them. (Phil digests this) Haven't you ever felt that way?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. “Lassie” does that to me almost every week.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) TV again! Jesus!  19

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You don’t like TV?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, | don’t. | think it makes people apathetic.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It’s just entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: And some entertainment has value. But mindless entertainment is useless. What are some of your interests?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Me? Oh, well, | have a wide range of interests.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (nods) Really? Like what? Phil suddenly feels cornered.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, like everything.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Everything, huh? Interested in paleontology?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Do you know very much about paleontology?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles) No.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grins) I’m the foremost authority.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: 20 OK. So, what's your favorite subject?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You mean like in school?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, | mean like in life.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh, that. Well...uh... music, | guess.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You sure don’t sound convinced.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, | am. Music. Definitely. | wanna be a musician.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You know, it’s really hard to be a musician. | take guitar lessons twice a week and that’s not nearly enough.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Well... It all depends on what you're after, right?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (confused) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, that’s if you want to be, say, a good or great musician.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (nods)  21 Right.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, Bobby Darin doesn’t really have a great voice, but he’s a very successful singer. Or what about Bob Dylan? He can’t sing at all.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he’s a great song writer. Phil waves his hand in total deprecation.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You can hire guys to do that.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, so...?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, you don’t necessarily have to be good to be famous. Look at Dean Martin. Lorraine consider this for a second, then dismisses the w

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: That's silly. Of course you do. What are you talking about? If it’s not their musical ability then it’s their presentation. It’s gotta be something. (Phil nods, good point; Lorraine remembers) Oh, y’know, tonight’s Hootenanny night at the Purple Onion, you have to come.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (confused) Hootenanny? Is that like when you square- dance and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (laughs) No. Hootenanny night means that it’s open microphone for anyone that wants to get up and sing or play or read a poem or do anything.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 22 (nods) Will you be there?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles and nods) Yes, | will. I’m going to sing a song tonight. You really should come, | mean, if you actually want to be a musician and all.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Right. | do. And | will. Lorraine suddenly stands.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta go. So, will | see you tonight at the Purple Onion?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sure. Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Great. Will you sing a song?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Do | have to?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, you don’t have to do anything you don’t want to do. None of these people are professionals, it’s just a hootenanny. But let’s face it, Phil, if you can’t sing at a hootenanny you'll never be famous as a musician.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods) Right.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles) OK. See ya there if you’re there.  23

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll be there. Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You, too. Lorraine departs. The Waitress steps up and hands Phil th leaves his entire 49 cents.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (smooth) Keep the change, sweetheart. The WAITRESS snorts and Phil leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. “STUDENTS FOR POLITICAL ACTION” OFFICE — DAY Lorraine stands in front of the office handing out yellow A big, green 1963 Cadillac Sedan devVille with very point and stops. The car’s electric window comes down revealing their early 40s. They are Lorraine’s MOM and DAD.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Get in the car, dear, before someone mugs you. Lorraine sighs and gets in the back seat of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Thank God, saved at last. INT. CADILLAC — DAY Lorraine’s Dad guns it and the car pulls away quickly. Da

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: 24 Did you forget you were having lunch with us?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: No, | didn’t. | tried to, but | couldn't. Her Mom looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: What have you got on your hands? Lorraine looks at her hands and sees purple stains.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Ink.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (smiles) It’s just your shade.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is nice, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: So, did you get an early start on solving the world’s problems today?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, | did. | think I'll be having a very big meeting Sunday night.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: | hope you do. But honestly, Lorraine, do you really think a bunch of college kids meeting in a low-rent downtown office are going to get those five Negro boys set free?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I certainly hope so. If nothing else it will raise people awareness of the problem. A line has to be drawn somewhere. Mom turns to Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: How did she turn out this way?  25

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It's got to be your fault, I’m never home.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You can say that again. Lorraine points at herself.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’m my own fault. And where are we going for lunch, if | may ask?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: The club.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Unmitigated decadence, and the food’s not very good.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You were such a happy little girl, Lorraine. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | developed a social conscience.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Well it certainly hasn’t made you any happier, | can tell you that. Why don’t you go away to Europe for a while — say a year — and make up your mind there?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | live here in America, mom. The problems of America are my problems. And my mind is made up.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Your mom’s not kidding, Lorraine. You want to go to Europe for a year, see the sights, go to school, don’t go to school. Anything you want, just say the word.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Oh, Dad, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You were accepted to the University of Florence, weren't you? You loved Italy when we all went there a few years ago. You ran around the house talking Italian for months.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (sighs wearily) This is such a bore. Lorraine’s Mom and Dad look at each other and shake their

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: So, Lorraine, how many people are you expecting at this rally of yours?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | don’t know. About a hundred, I’d say.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Well, how many chairs did you rent?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Fifty, but there’s twenty or thirty chairs there and | figure some people can stand.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: How’re you getting the rented chairs there?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Dad, please, I'll work it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Look, you want to be an organizer and organizers bring in the people. If they don’t bring in a decent crowd, you'll have to admit, they’re not worth much as an organizer, right?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly)  27 Yeah, | suppose.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: OK, how about this? If less than fifty people show up to your meeting, you consider doing something else. Anything else. More than fifty and I’ll shut up, for awhile. What do you say? But you have to give me a fair count.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: All | did was agree to go to lunch, I’m not here to negotiate any deals.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Just think about it, OK? That's all | ask.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. Lorraine sighs deeply, lost in the vast expanse of the ba sweater pocket, but she still doesn’t have any cigarettes

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S BEDROOM — DAY Phil sits on his bed noodling with his guitar. He has the glances at it over the top of the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Folk songs, folk songs ... Crap! | don’t know any folk songs. (focuses on the newspaper) Hey! Lyndon Baines Johnson, Lady Bird Johnson, Lynda Bird Johnson and Luci Baines Johnson? They all have the same initials. How weird! Phil’s Dad walks past the bedroom door, sees the newspape

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: There’s the newspaper. What's it doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I’m reading it.  Phil sighs. 28

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Great day in the morning, what next? So, what’s up?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Y’know, I’ve been meaning to speak to you. (he comes in and sits down on the bed) So, Phil, what are you doing? You've been out of high school for six months.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I’m working at the shoe store. Knockin’ ‘em dead, too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It means, Dad, that working at the shoe store is a bore.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: You don't like it? Find another job.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Like what? Working in a gas station?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t you have some goal? Some ambition?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (guffaws) Yeah, | wanna be president and get my brains blown out.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shocked)  29 That’s not nice.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It sure wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What's with you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Now come on, you must care about something?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (timidly) Well...

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Goon.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, | like playing the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (confused) You took lessons for about three weeks, then dropped out. How serious can you be about that?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (serious) Hey! People can be serious about things in their own ways, can’t they?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (unconvinced) | suppose. Look, Phil, what about college? His Father lights a Viceroy cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... I'll probably go to community college in the fall.  30

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: | meant, a university. What about State? | went to State. Phil points at his Dad’s cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Could | have cigarette? His Dad shakes a cigarette out of the pack and gives him

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: You smoke too much.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So do you. | didn’t get into State. His Dad lights Phil’s cigarette with a match, then his ow

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: If your grades are good at the community college you could get in.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well... Phil shrugs and puffs on his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: You just don’t care, do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Not about that.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: So what do you care about?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey! Come on, Dad, lay off, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Fine. So what are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 31 | have a date. His Dad grabs the wastebasket and uses it as an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Really? Have | met her?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. | just met her today at the music store. She’s a cute folkie girl that’s really committed to all kinds of things.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (interested) Really? Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (waves his hand) Oh, you know, Negroes and equality and things like that.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (impressed) Yeah, things like that. Well, she sounds interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, she is. And cute, too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Maybe you should become a folkie, then you’d be committed to all kinds of things, too.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking about it. The conversation grinds to an uncomfortable halt. They bo other. Finally, his Dad points at the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Go on, Elvis, play something. Phil quickly considers for a moment, then hits upon a pos  32

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | think I’ve got it!

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What song to play. Phil opens his beginning guitar book, finds what he’s loo play and sing “/f | Had a Hammer.”

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (singing) If | had a hammer ?’'d hammer in the mornin’ ’'d hammer in the evenin’ All over this land I'd hammer out danger ?’'d hammer out warnin’ l’d hammer out love between My brothers and my— Phil’s Dad looks at his watch and jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: —Holy Christ! Look at the time, | gotta get dressed. His Dad abruptly exits.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: —Sisters ... Phil sighs, picks up his cigarette, which has gone out, a takes his guitar over to the mirror and begins posing aga

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: The one, the only, Phil Buckley!  33 Phil strums the guitar, adds in the sound of the cheering cigarette like he’s Frank Sinatra.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S HOUSE/ LIVING ROOM — NIGHT Phil steps into the living room all dressed up and ready hand. His mother, father and brother all sit watching the eating TV dinners at folding TV tables (Ronald Reagan is Borax,” saying, “I’m standing here in a borax mine . . .” away from the TV for more than a brief second.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Where ya goin’

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: None o’ your beeswax, ratfink.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Phil's got a date with a folkie girl. This catches his Mother and brother's interest.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: What's a folkie girl?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You know, mom, like Mary from Peter, Paul & Mary. She’s hot stuff, too.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, she is a lovely girl.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I’m not going out with her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: 34 So, where ya goin’?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) To the Purple Onion.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That's a folk club, right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah, what of it?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So, what's up? Are you suddenly becoming a folkie like Bob Dylan?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Maybe | am and maybe I’m not!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: And you’re performing?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (coughs) Yeah. All three look at him in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: But Phil, you don’t know how to play the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yes | do. (everyone looks at him in silence) Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, just remember one thing, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 35 Yeah. What's that?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The answer is blowin’ in the wind. This gets a laugh from his family as they all simultaneou suddenly mesmerized in rapt silence as a new show begins. EXT. PHIL’S HOUSE — NIGHT Phil gets outside holding his guitar case. He lights up a windbreaker jacket and poses like James Dean. He looks ba his family through the front window illuminated in flicke cigarette between his teeth and walks purposefully down t EXT. PHIL’S BLOCK — NIGHT (Digital Effect) Phil walks up the block, passing house after house that a them with the same flickering, radiant blue TV light illu flicks his butt, hunches his shoulders and heads off into

dialogues.speaker: ACT TWO
dialogues.text: EXT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT Phil comes walking up to the front of the Purple Onion, a scene. There are folkies all over the place. All the men thin ties and the women are wearing skirts and dresses. T the boys, girls with their hair up or wearing babushkas, men and the women. Almost everybody smokes cigarettes. Phil approaches warily. Who are these people? He knows no that is, who stands in front of the club handing out flye

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Please come to this meeting tomorrow, it’s really important. See what you can do, OK? The person takes the flyer and one step later tosses it o pained, goes over and picks it up. She sees Phil standing over.  36

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You made it. Phil steps up.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | said | would, didn’t I. Lorraine gives him a hug and a kiss, which Phil finds ver his 34 flyer, but keeps holding onto his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. Will you be here tomorrow for the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah, | think | will.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You gonna sing a song tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What song?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I’m not telling. What song are you singing?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: “If | Had a Hammer.” (Phil grimaces like he was kicked in the gut) What's the matter? Don’t you like it?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 37 (grins painfully) No, no, it’s a great Peter, Paul & Mary song.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: It's a Weavers song. Peter, Paul & Mary re-did it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (not listening) Yeah, right, the Wheelers. They're great, too. Just then a slouchy fellow named TERRY, with thick, black long, shaggy hair, walks up and gets a big hug and a kiss distresses Phil.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry. You made it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Said | would.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: This is Phil.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Phil. He puts out his hand. Phil somewhat begrudgingly shakes T

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. You, too.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (to Terry) Are you singing a song?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (frowning)  38 Really? How come?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause | don’t want to. Phil looks at Terry with sudden respect, then glances dow — why the hell is he singing a song? Phil is about to bri turns away and yells.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Make way for the pregnant lady! A good-looking couple in their mid-twenties comes walking cases. They are ALVIN & DEBBIE and Debbie is six months p Lorraine hugs and kisses. Lorraine introduces Phil and Te

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Phil, Terry; Debbie and Alvin. Everybody shakes hands and says hello. Phil attempts to s

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Uh, Lorraine — Lorraine is paying attention to Alvin & Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: So, are you guys going to sing?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re all signed up and everything. All | need is a few drinks first.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Me, too. Lorraine and Debbie both laugh. Phil looks at Terry who s then he turns back to Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Um... Lorraine points at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: 39 Phil's singing a song, too. Alvin slaps Phil on the back.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Good, | thought maybe we were the only ones. Man oh man, we’ve been practicing our heads off.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I'll bet we’ve rehearsed this song a thousand times. Phil looks like he’s about to say something when Lorraine leads him inside.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Let’s get you signed up so you don’t miss your big chance to sing. Phil’s gonna be a famous singer some day, like Bobby Darin and Al Martino.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Boy oh boy are you in the wrong place. Lorraine hustles Phil inside and the others happily follo

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: She means, Dean Martin.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: | got news for you, Dean Martin wouldn’t be caught dead in this joint. INT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT Lorraine, Phil and the others enter the Purple Onion, a s much full. Lorraine points down toward the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’ve got the front table staked out with my guitar. We'll be right there. Terry, Alvin and Debbie head to the table.  40 Lorraine takes Phil over to the M.C., a 40-year old guy w behind a crude lighting board. The M.C. looks at Phil and M.C. Who’s he?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: A friend. M.C. You sure have a lot of friends.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact | do, what's it to you? M.C. Nothing. Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (nods at Phil) He wants to sing. M.C. Then sing out, my friend, sing out. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Phil Buckley. M.C. OK, Phil there you go. The M.C. writes “Phil” at the bottom of the Hootenanny li listed above him. Phil gulps, thinking what have | done? M.C. Keep in mind, though, friend, that with ten acts ahead of you there’s a pretty good chance you won't get to go on at all.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (mumbles to himself) God willing.  41

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (encouraging) Oh, now. You said you want to be a musician, right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Here you go. (to the M.C.) Are we set for tomorrow? The M.C. steps up to Lorraine and whispers in her ear. M.C. Sure. Uh, Lorraine... ?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah? M.C. (shakes his head) Later. Lorraine and Phil walk across the club.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (excited) I’m so glad Terry made it, | really think you two will hit it off. He’s really smart. | met him at a sit-in, and | met Alvin & Debbie at an SDS meeting. They are very committed to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What cause?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: The cause of freedom and equality.  42

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods) Oh. Right. That. (casually) By the way, what are some of your favorite folk songs?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (thinks) Well, | really like Bob Dylan’s “Talking Word War 3 Blues.”

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shakes his head; sighs) | don’t know that one. The guitar is starting to feel like 500 pound weight to P

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Bring your guitar tomorrow night to the meeting and we can have our own little hootenanny after- ward. |’ll teach it to you. That sounds like a fine idea to Phil, who nods and grins.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Boss. As they cross the room, Lorraine waves and says hi to jus wave and say hi back to her. Phil’s impressed. They arrive at the table down near the stage where Terry, drinking a pitcher of beer and are all smoking cigarettes Phil quickly sits on her other side. Lorraine leans across the table to speak and whispers wit Phil.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Wow! He looks like Troy Donahue. Where’d you find him?  43

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: At the music store. | think he’s got potential, too. He just needs some guidance.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: From you, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (considers; looks at Phil) ... Perhaps. Phil and Terry look at each other past Lorraine’s shapely

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (to Phil) What song are you singing?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I’m still thinking about it. What are some your favorite folk songs?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: | don’t like folk songs.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (confused) Then what are you doing here? Terry glances at Lorraine’s derriere, then up to Phil. Ph that he too is there for the same reason.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You a student?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Uh, no. I’m gonna start at SCC in the fall.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (grins) Harvard of the highway. It’s like high school with ashtrays. | went for a year. Workin’?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 44 Ata shoe store. You?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: | work on the college newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods; impressed) Your parents rich?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No, not really. (whispers and points) But Lorraine’s sure are.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (interested) Really? But she seems so...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: . .. Down to Earth?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It’s the rejection of the money. Very common.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (fascinated) It is?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Sure, take a look around you. What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (looks around) People. Folkies.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Middle-class to upper-middle-class white people, with just a few token Negroes thrown in for color, whose own self-hatred causes them to have to pretend to help other people less fortunate than themselves to ease their guilt.  45

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (looks around) Huh. Across the table, Alvin & Debbie are having a discussion.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: So, when will you start looking for a new job? You said after the New Year, well it’s February.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: But, Deb, | like my job.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You like your job? Come on.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: All right, | don’t hate my job. I’ve had plenty of jobs I’ve hated, too. And then | don’t like waking up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: But Alvin, dear, you don’t make enough money. We're going to need more money soon. We might even have to buy a house.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: (holds up his hands) Whoa! Slow down, will you. I’m not ready for any of this. Debbie points at her protruding belly.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Too late.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Hey! Come on you guys, you're out in public, remember.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: There are times when his complacency makes me want to kill him.  46

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: But you've decided to have his child instead. Terry and Phil continue to talk.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, you’re up at State?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (nods) Yep.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, what are you taking up?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Time and space.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grins) I’m doin’ that right here, why go to State?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Less parental supervision. More parties. More chicks.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But don’t they make you take tests occasionally?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Occasionally, but school’s easy if you know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So what are really studying?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Computers.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Computers, huh? You really are into weird stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Computers aren’t so weird. Someday there'll be  47 hundreds of them, everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sure, if you say so. Lorraine sits back down between Phil and Terry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You boys getting acquainted? Both grunt in the affirmative. The bearded M.C. steps up onto the small stage and speaks M.C. I'd like to welcome everybody to the Purple Onion’s weekly Hootenanny night. This is the night when we get a preview of the up- coming folk stars of the future. I’d also like to announce a very important meeting to be held here tomorrow night to help arrange a defense fund for the Springfield Five. (Lorraine looks around and smiles) If you really care about the cause of freedom you'll make sure to be here. OK. Now let’s have some fun. Our first act of the evening is the husband and wife duo, Alvin & Debbie. Let’s give them a warm Purple Onion welcome. The audience applauds as Alvin & Debbie step up on stage.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. But don’t get Debbie too excited, she might have the baby right here. Debbie elbows him the ribs and the audience chuckles. The energetic rendition of “Rock Island Line”

Lorraine them.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You see, those endless hours of practicing pay off.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: (grinning) They sure do. Phil looks like he’s in pain. Debbie grabs the pitcher of

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That was pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: So, uh, you a big folk music fan?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No, not really. Folk music’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What kind of music do you like? Phil looks around to see if anyone is listening.  50

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (lowers his voice) | like rock & roll.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Me, too. Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | like Elvis.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah. He’s boss. And Chuck Berry.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lorraine returns to her seat between Phil and Terry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What are you boys talking about.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Rock & roll music.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (waves it away) That's for children. (points at the stage) Now that was music! Bebop-a-lula? Tutti fruitti, oh Rudy? Come on, boys, grow up. Phil and Terry both feel chastised. Lorraine sees someone

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Excuse me a sec, I’ve got work to do. Lorraine picks up a pile of her flyers and heads off. Lorraine cruises around the club handing out flyers. Yell table and quickly used as coasters, folded and put into p written on them, corners torn off, one gets folded up and table.  51 A yellow flyer comes down revealing four middle-aged peop ties and a woman in a dressy dress, all looking at the fl beer. They are: PETE, LEE, FRED and the woman is RONNIE. the FOUR FEATHERS. They all drink heartily and wave aroun

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Good. We ought to have a lot of people. But | still need you guys to be there.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Need? Oh, come on, Lorraine, you can handle this. I’m sure you've got everything completely under control.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, | do, but still. . .

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, don’t depend on me being there. You've got to finally handle things on your own.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | know.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: | remember the first meeting | organized. It was a garment-workers strike just after the war. Somewhere in Upstate New York.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Gloversville.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That's right, Gloversville. Lordy, they almost tore the house down.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Those were the days. The Four Feathers all toast and drink.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: 52 Good luck, tonight, you guys.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Thanks, you, too. And | just know your meeting will be great.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Lorraine walks away.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Shit! She’s not gonna be there. | was depending on her. The M.C. steps up beside Lorraine and takes her arm. M.C. Lorraine, you’ve got to help me.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Sure, Marty, how? (he tries to speak, but all that comes out are inaudible noises) What is it? M.C. You just have to sleep with me, Lorraine. You have to.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | do, huh? M.C. | love you Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Oh, for God’s sake. That's ridiculous. M.C.  53 (stung) Oh, it is, huh? You want to use the club tomorrow, right?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (indignant) You already said | could use the club tomorrow. M.C. Right. | did. And | mean it, too. And | don’t expect anything in return, either.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Don’t you? M.C. (smiles) Well...

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | thought you honestly cared about the Springfield Five. M.C. (distracted) Who? Oh, them. Yeah, | do. But Lorraine, please think of the good you could do, for me. Please. Lorraine turns and walks away, her expression saying, “Wh Lorraine returns to her table and sits back down. At which point MOUSTAPHA HAKIM arrives. He is a black man dark suit and tie, a round leather, African hat, sunglass beat-up guitar. Terry looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Greetings, folk fans.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You got here.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: 54 You didn’t think | would?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No, no, | did.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: And who are all of these nice-looking white people?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You know Lorraine. Moustapha shakes Lorraine’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (smiles) Lorraine. Always a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That's Alvin & Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Alvin, Debbie. They both shake his hand and both look uncomfortable doin

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: And this is Phil. Moustapha shakes Phil’s hand, then grabs a chair and seat

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Be prepared, the blues’re coming. Terry leans over to Moustapha and nods toward the back.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Canwe...

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Cool down, my friend. Everything in good time. Moustapha turns to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (nods)  55 You like the blues?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well... Like Chuck Berry.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Chuck Berry. That’s your idea of blues?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, rhythm and blues. How about Muddy Rivers?

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: That's Muddy Waters.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Right, but | hear he’s formed a group with Johnny Rivers. Moustapha turns to Terry.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s go. Terry grins devilishly as he and Moustapha head off toget Lorraine turns back to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What do you think of Terry?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He’s interesting.  56 The M.C. steps up to the small blackboard and erases Alvi of the list. The next name is “Bobby Lee.” M.C. Ladies and gentlemen, the Purple Onion welcomes back the angry, intense, and always energetic, Bobby Lee Baker! The audience applauds excitedly as BOBBY LEE BAKER, a bro dressed in black with a beret and a jazz patch. He steps cigarette smoldering between his lips irritating his eyes guitar, entirely ignoring the audience. He flicks his cig see that it lands in an inattentive WOMAN ’s drink.

dialogues.text: We're living in a world of oppression. White people hold down the black people. Rich people hold down the poor people. Some- times it makes me so mad | can barely talk. Bile builds up in my throat and | can’t even spit. Those are the times when you'd kinda like to see the whole shebang go up in one big ball of fire, know what | mean? The audience looks back at him wide-eyed and silent. Bobb launches into an intense rendition of “/n My Time of Dyin picking, as well as the use of a bottleneck.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. SDS.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) They do. | go ‘cause there’s usually cute chicks there. (that seems like a good reason to Phil) And cute folkie chicks that are always screaming about freedom and equality sometimes put out, know what | mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (he knows) So, then you don’t really care about freedom and equality and civil rights?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure | do, but not as much as getting laid. Terry wags his eyebrows. Phil grins. We see Lorraine’s stack of yellow flyers in her hand as s up to a table where three very cool-looking, beat-types s smoking cigarettes and don’t notice Lorraine . They are:

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE

dialogues.text: Hey, Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (grunts) Urgh.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Wow, you folks sure look mellow.

dialogues.speaker: MARYLOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, we are.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Mellowville.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hooo! Lorraine furrows her brow and leans forward to MaryLou.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you guys?

dialogues.speaker: MARYLOU
dialogues.text: Wrong? Nothin’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: MARYLOU, BILL
dialogues.text: (together, grinning) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARYLOU, BILL
dialogues.text: (together) Yeah.

dialogues.text: Lorraine! Over here! Lorraine sees a table with two couples in black and white  62 this distance we can tell they are smashed. Lorraine winc

dialogues.text: Mindy, what on Earth are you doing here?

dialogues.text: You told us about this hootenanny thing on Saturday nights and we decided to come and see for ourselves. Are you singing tonight, Lorraine?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yes, | am. (points at Phil) So’s he. This is my friend, Phil. Mindy shakes Phil’s hand. She looks him up and down and o

dialogues.text: So now that you've started going new places, you should come to this meeting here tomorrow night, for the Springfield Five.

dialogues.speaker: MINDY

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (thinks)  64 Sunday night? “Lassie,” then “Ed Sullivan,” then “Gunsmoke,” why?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Ring-a-ding-ding!

dialogues.text: Never mind. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: The TV generation.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Are you from another generation?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Apparently. (waves her hand) This one. Where some things still matter. Ring- a-ding-ding? “Lassie” and “Gunsmoke.” Good God! You people and your mindless amusements.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey, | didn’t invent this stuff. Blame Edison. Lorraine stops and turns to face Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: But it’s not reality, Phil. We live in reality, where there’s suffering and injustice and war.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 65 | think you forgot locust and cattle disease. Lorraine gets angry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: It’s not funny!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Damn, you are one serious girl. What do you want to be when you grow up? Abraham Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Or a modern female version of him. Phil takes Lorraine’s ink-stained hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | have a great idea that will help all of society.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Let’s drink some more beer. Did | mention that beer is like liquid bread?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. They sit down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but | like getting drunk.  66 They toast and drink.
