Some say this world of trouble Is the only one we need But I’m waiting for the mornin’ When the new world is revealed Oh when the new world is revealed Oh when the new world is revealed Oh Lord | want to be in that number Oh when the new world is revealed Oh when the saints go marching in Oh when the saints go marching in Oh Lord | want to be in that number When the saints go marching in The Four Feathers bring down the house. The audience clap Lorraine, Terry and the whole table join them loudly. Phi total panic. His hands are sweating and he looks nauseous

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to no one in particular) I think | gotta go. Phil starts to stand and Lorraine reaches out and takes h  71

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | can’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Sure you can. You'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (seriously) No, no, you don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (smiles reassuringly) Of course | do. Everyone feels this way their first time.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but these people are really good.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Right. And their not professionals.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but they really seem to... care.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Well, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (good question) Um... Lorraine spots someone she knows and quickly exits.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me. Phil is in a deep quandary. He glances over at the door—h one would be the wiser. Meanwhile, Terry is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  72

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (sighs deeply) Lorraine is doing the song that | was gonna do. | was all ready, too, y'know. | practiced the song like a hundred times. But now I’m screwed. Terry takes pity on Phil.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Come with me. Everything’ll be just fine.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Just come on. Terry leads Phil out the back door. EXT. THE PURPLE ONION/ALLEY — NIGHT Terry and Phil come out into the under-lit alley behind t a big, fat, crooked cigarette. Phil can’t believe it. He they're alone.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shocked) That's marijuana, isn’t it? Terry nods, lighting up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Say it louder, maybe a cop’ll hear you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (frightened) But, it’s illegal.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Doesn't it lead to hard drugs like morphine and heroin?  73

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (grins fiendishly) Whoa! Slow down, tiger. One step at a time. Terry hands Phil the burning joint. Phil hesitantly takes brief moment of consideration, shrugs, then takes a hit. INT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT Lorraine sits back down in her seat, looking somewhat emb her hair. She notices that Phil and Terry’s chairs are em though people are looking at her and pulls her sweater cl the microphone, grinning, his hair askew. M.C. Ladies and gentlemen, I’m proud to welcome back a Purple Onion regular, a dedicated fighter for equality and justice, and the organizer of the Springfield Five defense fund meeting here tomorrow at eight. Let’s give a warm hand to Lorraine Dempsey! Lorraine throws a last look at the empty seats on either used to be, shakes her head, smiles and heads up on stage

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Sometimes it’s not easy to do what's right. We're always tempted to go the other way. To take the wrong path. And sometimes we don’t even know which path we’re on. Justice, freedom and equality are not just words. They’re goals that we have to work for. That's why | strongly urge you to be here tomorrow night at eight P.M. for a very important meeting. We can make a difference . . . EXT. THE PURPLE ONION/ALLEY — NIGHT Phil and Terry are just finishing the joint. Their eyes a They're stoned.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grinning)  74 Man, If | had a hammer I'd hurt myself. They both laugh like total idiots.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: So, what’dya think?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: About what? (Terry waves his hand, Phil grins) Oh, yeah. Boss. Is it always like this?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Wow. How much is this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Pretty cheap.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: And you got it from... um (he can’t remember) That Negro man.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Moustapha. Right.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Does he grow it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: No, man. He gets it from someone else who gets it from someone else who brings it from Panama or Mexico or wherever.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 75 Wow! Too much! | feel like I’m in Panama or Mexico or wherever now.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. | know what you mean. Wherever’s where it’s at.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: And that’s where we are. Where it’s at.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. They start laughing idiotically again. INT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT Lorraine proceeds to sing “/f | Had a Hammer’ in a pretty

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (singing) If | had a hammer ?’'d hammer in the mornin’ ’'d hammer in the evenin’ All over this land I'd hammer out danger ?’'d hammer out warnin’ ’'d hammer out love between My brothers and my sisters All over this land If | had a bell I'd ring it in the mornin’ I'd ring it in the evenin’ All over this land I'd ring out danger I'd ring out warnin’ I'd ring out love between My brothers and my sisters All over this land If | had a song — EXT. THE PURPLE ONION/ALLEY — NIGHT  76 Terry is holding forth to a stoned and completely rapt Ph

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Elvis and Chuck Berry and Little Richard and Jerry Lee Lewis all had their careers taken from them, man. Where'd they all go? What happened to rock & roll? They were stopped, drafted, arrested, persecuted. Their careers were stopped. Why? It’s because there’s a conspiracy to stop rock & roll, and I’m telling you it’s the same guys that killed Kennedy. Phil has no idea what Terry’s talking about.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Killed Kennedy? Lee Harvey Oswald killed Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (lights up) Ah ha! That’s what they’d like you to believe.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Then Jack Ruby killed Oswald.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Pretty convenient, huh? Get rid of the patsy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But | saw it on TV.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah? | see “Howdy Doody” on TV but that don’t make it true. Phil looks all around, freaking out. INT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT Lorraine finishes the song with a flurry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Well, | have a hammer  77 And | have a bell And | have a song to sing All over this land It's the hammer of justice It’s the bell of free-e-dom It's a song about love between My brother and my sisters All over this land Lorraine receives a big round of applause. She glances at furrows her brow. The audience hollers for “More!”

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: All right. Now we’re all gonna sing a song together, because we all have to stick together if we’re gonna make things better. And we can all start by being here tomorrow night at eight to help put together the defense fund for the Springfield Five. OK? Now, instead of singing “the” union, let’s all sing “our’ union, OK? And if you don’t know the verses, just join in for the chorus. Lorraine begins to play the melody to “The Battle Hymn of becomes “Solidarity Forever.” The audience hesitantly joi with each chorus.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (singing) Solidarity forever Solidarity forever Solidarity forever For our union makes us strong. When our union’s inspiration Through the worker's blood shall run There can be no power greater Anywhere beneath the sun Yet what force on Earth is weaker Than the feeble strength of one But our union makes us strong Solidarity forever Solidarity forever  78 Solidarity forever For our union makes us strong. It is we who plowed the prairies Built the cities where they trade Dug the mines and built the workshops Endless miles of railroad laid Now we stand outcast and starving ‘Mid the wonders we have made But our union makes us strong (continued) LORRAINE (cont.) Solidarity forever Solidarity forever Solidarity forever For our union makes us strong. They have taken untold millions That they never toiled to earn But without our brain and muscle Not a single wheel will turn We can break their haughty power Gain our freedom when we learn That our union makes us strong. Solidarity forever Solidarity forever Solidarity forever For our union makes us strong. In our hands is placed the power Greater than their hoarded gold Greater than the might of atoms Magnified a thousand fold We can bring to birth a new world From the ashes of the old For our union makes us strong. (Lorraine call out) Now, come on! Everybody! (everybody joins in) Solidarity forever Solidarity forever Solidarity forever  79 For our union makes us strong. There is the biggest round of applause of the evening. Ev Lorraine returns to her table to the smiles of her friend two empty seats and frowns. Debbie is drunk and gives Lor another cigarette, which Lorraine gratefully takes. Alvin belly while drinking and smoking with the other.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (drunk) Good job, Lorraine. Solidarity forever!

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: (drunk) That was great, Lorraine, just great. (points at Debbie’s belly) This kid is gonna grow up in a better world than what we got. What we got was shit. Old and worn- out and busted. Lorraine looks all around.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Have you seen Terry or Phil? Alvin and Debbie look around.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: No. Lorraine stands.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I'll be back in a sec. Lorraine leaves. Debbie drunkenly turns back to Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: And that’s why you've got to get a better job.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus Christ! | don’t give a shit about a better job, can’t you get that through your thick skull?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: 80 | get it, but I’m not buyin’ it. Phil and Terry return and they’re toasted and giggling. T thumbs-up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I'll go get some more beer.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Good thinking. Phil sits down beside Moustapha.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, uh... Moustachio—

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: —Moustapha.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Exactly. So, what's it like being a Negro?

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (laughs) Boy, you are stoned.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (looks around) Yeah? | guess so. Everything has sort of an echo.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: “What's it like being a Negro?” Shit! What’s it like being a silly little stoned white boy?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grins foolishly) Not bad. Pretty good, actually.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: But that wears off. Bein’ black don’t. Everywhere you go, all the time, you still a Negro, and you’re generally outnumbered, unless you're in the ghetto. All the white folk are friendly here tonight, but that don’t mean they won't be back out lynchin’ niggers  81 again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (this is heavy) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Wow! Golly gee-whiz! (points at Phil) | was down in Birmingham last year for Dr. King’s big march, the one where he got arrested. You hear about that?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Uh... maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (shakes his head sadly) Shit! You don’t know anything, do you? Your head’s as empty as a bucket, that’s why you hear an echo. What're you doin’ here, anyway? You ain’t no folkie. You ain’t committed to no causes. Phil points at Lorraine who is talking to a guy at anothe

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: She invited me.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTAPHA
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, the great recruiter, Sweet Lorraine. (gets serious) Y’know, man, we all stand for somethin’, even if we don’t know what it is. You can either stand for something on purpose or by mistake, but either way you still do. Think about it. Phil does think about it. When he looks up Moustapha has left sitting at the table. He immediately gets paranoid, looking at him. He can’t figure out what to do with his h nails. He stops himself and lights a cigarette from a pac  82 Lorraine sits down beside Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You missed my songs.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You sang more than one?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Two. They went over very well.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well that’s cool. She looks Phil in the eyes and shakes her head in disappr

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (whispers) You and Terry smoked pot?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (stutters) Um... Thatis... We,uh...

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (shocked) That's so irresponsible.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What'dya mean?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Phil, you’re about to go on. Phil waves his hand, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, no, no. There’s still gotta be six or seven people ahead of me. He said they probably wouldn’t get to me anyway. Phil points at the blackboard and there are still quite a the M.C. suddenly picks up the eraser and erases all the Now Phil is next. Phil’s mouth drops open in panic.  83 M.C. Due to several last minute cancellations, may | introduce one more good friend of Lorraine’s, Phil Butler! Phil gets a squeeze on the arm from Lorraine and a thumbs Alvin and Debbie. Phil makes his way onstage, which is a very long walk. He strums his guitar, coughs, squints up at the bright light

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That’s Buckley, not Butler. The audience could really give a shit less. And sadly, Ph what to play. This is the worst moment of his entire life hearing and sight — he can hear people breathing, puffing chairs, all looking at him expectantly. Phil moves closer to the lower, guitar microphone and get shoves the microphone into the hole in the guitar and pro version of “If | Had a Hammer.”

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: If | had a h-h-h-hammer Pd h-h-h-hammer in the mornin’ I'd h-h-h-hammer in the evenin’ All over this crazy old land, oh yeah! There is a big solid moment when the audience has absolut watching. They look befuddled. Phil doesn’t care. In for goes for it...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: l'd-a hammer out danger ?’'d-a hammer out warnin’ ’'d-a hammer out-a love between My brothers and my sisters All over this land Phil does the Chuck Berry duckwalk. The audience is suffi begin to clap along, hooting and hollering. Phil grabs tw together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If | had a bell I'd ring-a-ding-ding it in the mornin’ I'd ring-a-ding-ding it in the evenin’ All over this land I'd ring-a-ding-ding out danger I'd ring-a-ding-ding out warnin’ I'd ring-a-ding-ding out love between My brothers and my sisters All over this land If | had a song You can just bet I’d sing it in the mornin’ And I'd sing it in the evenin’ All over this nutty old land I'd sing out danger I'd sing out warnin’ I'd sing out love between My brothers and my sisters All over this land (gives a big pelvis shake) Ha! There is a huge round of applause for Phil. He takes a bo turn of events. The M.C. comes on. M.C. That's Phil Buckley, not Butler. Sorry about that, buddy. Very funny routine. You ought to be on Ed Sullivan. Anyway, thanks for coming to the Purple Onion’s weekly Hootenany. And don’t forget about the defense fund meeting for the Springfield Five tomorrow. And thanks for coming. Last call. Many people stand up to leave. Lorraine looks at Phil in astonishment as he gulps down a slaps Phil on the back. 84  85

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: This guy is a wild man.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | can’t decide whether that was inspired or just pure nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | don’t know. They all stand to leave. As everyone files out we can see strewn hither, thither and yon. Lorraine sighs, picking s exits.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT In front of the club Phil and Terry are watching Lorraine give out yellow flyers.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Remember the meeting is here tomorrow at eight. Many people say that they'll be there. Finally, the only Terry. Lorraine confronts Phil and Terry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | can’t believe you missed my songs.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (abashed) Sorry. Lorraine steps up to Phil’s side and takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Goodnight Terry.  86

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, goodnight Terry. Nice meeting you. Terry sees what's what.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you too. ‘Night, Lorraine. Terry leaves. Lorraine and Phil look at each other. The n building go out, plunging Lorraine and Phil into darkness

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You hurt my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sorry. Did you like my song?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Honestly, no.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (hurt) You didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You faked it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But they liked it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (confused) Hmmm... Phil takes advantage of this moment and kisses Lorraine. other.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’m not really sure | like you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grins)  87 Me neither. He kisses her again. Just then the M.C. steps out of the separate. The M.C. sees them lurking there. M.C. Is that you, Lorraine?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. M.C. Still recruiting for the cause?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Up yours! M.C. Goodnight He leaves. Lorraine and Phil kiss again, longer. Lorraine

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Lorraine walks away and Phil watches her go. Finally, Phi direction.

dialogues.text: EXT. PHIL’S HOUSE — DAY The morning sun shines over the top of Phil’s house. Phil out of the garage, pulls the rope and starts the noisy en INT. PHIL’S BEDROOM — DAY  88 Phil lies in bed asleep. The sound of the lawnmower engin glances at the clock and sees that it’s after 10:00 A.M. life. He looks down at the pillow and sees a three-inch c

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to himself) | feel like | got hit on the head with a hammer. Phil glances over at his dresser where three folded-up ye scratches his head and a wistful smiles crosses his face

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Sweet Lorraine. (smiles) | knocked ‘em dead. They loved me. INT. PHIL’S HOUSE/HALLWAY OUTSIDE BATHROOM — DAY We can see the closed door of the bathroom and hear the w We can also hear Phil singing in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (O.S./singing) If | had a h-h-hammer ?’'d hammer a lot Then I'd h-h-hammer some more Then I'd hammer on the door ’'d h-h-hammer all the nails Stickin’ out of the log Then I'd h-h-hammer all the ants And I’d hammer all the dogs Phil’s mother and his brother meet in the hallway, stop a

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What's with him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) | guess he had a good time last night.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Holy Toledo, | sure hope he doesn’t turn into  89 a folkie.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (sighs) It might be good for him. He’s seemed awfully aimless lately. And those folk people do seem to care about things.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Yeah, | guess. But Ma...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (confused) Do people just change like that?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sometimes, | suppose. His mother walks away. Dan considers her words for a seco away. Phil keeps right on singing in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (O.S./singing) I'd h-h-hammer all the bugs Then I'd h-h-hammer all the bats Then I'd h-h-hammer all the cats Then I'd h-h-hammer all the gnats . . . INT. PHIL’S BEDROOM — DAY Phil stands in front of his mirror with wet hair, his gui poor Ed Sullivan imitation.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We have a really big shew. For all of you folk fans that like Bob Dylan and Peter, Paul & Mary, | now give you the new voice of the nation, Phil Buckley! The crowds cheer wildly. Phil acts humble as he raises hi  90

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you. EXT. PHIL’S HOUSE — DAY Phil’s father is raking up the cut grass on the front law

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Here, let me help.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Let me help.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (amazed) Huh. I’m not sure I’ve ever heard you say anything like that before.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (seriously) Look, dad, if we’re all gonna get by in this world then | guess we’d better pitch in and help each other, right?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Right. He hands Phil the rake. Phil shrugs, takes it and begins piles of cut grass and puts them in a trash can.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: So, how was your date last night?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Good. Real good.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: And you got up and sang?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yep. And they liked me, too.  91

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned. I’m really glad to hear it, Phil. So you’re going to become a musician now?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Dad, | am a musician.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) OK. All right. You sure got your money's worth out of those two weeks of guitar lessons.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (defensive) It was three weeks, OK? And I’d’ve kept it up, but my fingers hurt really bad, all right? His father throws his hands up in capitulation.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: All right, all right.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S HOUSE/KITCHEN — DAY Phil’s mother makes lunch while Phil lectures her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Is it right for a woman to make less money doing the same job as a man?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's right. And is it right for Negroes to have to sit at the back of the bus?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: Well, no.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 92 That's right, no. It’s time to stand up and let our voices be heard. His mother scoops gobs of mayonnaise into the tuna fish a

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: So you sang a song last night?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (casually) Great. They loved me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really? That’s very nice. Phil walks away.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, they’re a good crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. PHIL’S HOUSE/BACKYARD — DAY Phil and Dan play catch with mitts and a hardball in the

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So then the same guys that stopped rock & roll killed Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (fascinated) Really? How?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's very complicated and you probably won't  93 understand, but it’s what’s called a “conspiracy,” which means that a bunch of people were involved.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yeah? How many?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | don’t know, but a bunch. So then, after they stopped rock & roll by sending Elvis away to the army, they decided they had to kill Kennedy to keep him quiet.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Really? That's creepy. What else did they do?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: They set Lee Harvey Oswald up as a patsy, then had Jack Ruby shoot him to shut him up. Dan is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Do mom and dad know this?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shrugs helplessly) Probably not. They accept anything they’re told. Just like robots.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXT. THE PURPLE ONION — DAY Max, the beatnik, loiters around in front of the Purple O Lorraine comes driving up in her parents’ enormous green of space jammed with wooden folding chairs. The trunk bul with twine.

dialogues.speaker: MAX

dialogues.text: That’s not nice.  94

dialogues.speaker: MAX

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Disparaging remarks about religion aren’t funny.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | hung out with some buddies, why?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You said you were coming to the Purple Onion?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: | didn’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Then why’d you say you were coming?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Lorraine, | don’t owe you anything. I’m here unloading chairs out of a sense of commitment, not out of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: | just don’t like it when people say things and don’t do them, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well get used to it. Max and Lorraine silently unload the wooden chairs and le Both of them throw hurt, reproving glances at one another

dialogues.text: (to himself) And | say, the Springfield Five must be freed or none of us is safe. If five Springfield youths can be put in jail for absolutely no good reason, then | say, who’s next? (turns and yells) Mom!

dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Have | got any clean socks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Thanks. (continues) So | say, free the Springfield Five, that’s what | say. And damnit, | mean what | say. Phil exits his bedroom. INT. dialogues.text: You're not going back to the Purple Onion again, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (total disdain)  96 Nothin’. Only Ed Sullivan is about to go on now and The Beatles are gonna be on show tonight, that’s all. Phil is stricken.

dialogues.text: The Beatles. Uh! | have to see them!

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So sit down.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BUCKLEY

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
dialogues.text: That's right, Phil. And what about the rights of the Negroes and women? Dan looks right at Phil and speaks flatly.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The Beatles, Phil. “She Loves You, Yeah, Yeah, Yeah,” “| Wanna Hold Your Hand,” “Twist & Shout.”

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (immobilized) Uh... INT. THE PURPLE ONION — NIGHT  97 Lorraine comes rushing into the Purple Onion in a fluster bags, as well as her guitar. The M.C. is waiting for her M.C. For God’s sake, Lorraine, I’m gonna miss Ed Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hi. Am | late?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Are you late?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Am |?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (flatly) You missed it. It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (casually) Whoops. Sorry about that. Did it go all right?  100

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Look around. You see anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (looks around) Uh...no. Break up early?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (flatly) Yeah, it broke up early.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So, you wanna get a cup of coffee? Lorraine laughs sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: You don't give a shit at all, do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: About anything.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (offended) Hey! | care about a lotta stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, like music.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Ha! You can’t even play the Goddamn guitar. | mean, for Christ sake, how are you ever going to be a musician?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: | told ya, it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: 101 So is getting hit by a meteor. Y’know, you're what the world is coming to, Phil, and | don’t like it! Apathy and inability. It’s a really bad combination.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you? | thought we had a really good time last night.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: (pointing) You didn’t show up to my Goddamn meeting!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I said | was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: So what? Does saying your sorry push the erase button or something? | just threw out five pounds of potato salad. Ya know what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (uncertain) What?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Drop dead! Lorraine turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Italy. (she waves) Arivederci! Lorraine stomps away, disappearing into the night. Phil s

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Huh.  102 Just then Terry comes running up from the other direction

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Did | miss the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We both did.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Did you see The Beatles on Ed Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, they were boss!

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I’m never cuttin’ my hair again.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Boy oh boy, those girls were really screaming, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Man, they were crying. I’ve never seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: | like John.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Really. | like George. He sure can play that guitar. They both looked geeked up.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You just missed Lorraine. She threw a hairy fit at me for missing the meeting. Terry waves his hand disdainfully.  103

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: The Springfield Five. | mean, who gives a crap? Not me.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Not me, either.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Wanna come over my place? We could smoke some more reefer, y'know, maybe jam a little bit? What'dya say?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Really? Cool.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Cool’s out, man. No one’s saying it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Really? No kidding? What're they saying instead.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Tuff. T-U-F-F. It’s really tuff, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nods) OK. Cool. | mean,Tuff. They both exit. We stay on the dark and empty exterior of last night’s cheering crowd and Ronnie, the female member speaking.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you very much. Y’know, it just so happens we do have one more song.
